raw_text: While previous work uses the Stanford CoreNLP toolkit to identify characters and extract typed dependencies for them, we found this approach to be too slow for the scale of our data (a total of 1.8 billion tokens); in particular, syntactic parsing, with cubic complexity in sentence length, and out-of-the-box co reference resolution (with thousands of potential antecedents) prove to be 3All categories are described using the Stanford typed dependencies (de Marneffe and Manning, 2008), but any syn tactic formalism is equally applicable
clean_text: While previous work uses the Stanford CoreNLP toolkit to identify characters and extract typed dependencies for them, we found this approach to be too slow for the scale of our data (a total of 1.8 billion tokens); in particular, syntactic parsing, with cubic complexity in sentence length, and out-of-the-box co reference resolution (with thousands of potential antecedents) prove to be 3All categories are described using the Stanford typed dependencies (de Marneffe and Manning, 2008), but any syntactic formalism is equally applicable.

clean_text: Bjorne et al. showed that deep dependency analyses in the well-established Stanford Dependency (SD) scheme (de Marneffe and Manning, 2008) can successfully be utilised in extracting graphs that express semantic entities as node sand relationship arguments as edges but are limited to one node per syntactic token.

raw_text: In this paper, we describe 1) a new dependency conversion (Section 3) of the Penn Treebank (Marcus, et al, 1993) along with the associated dependency label scheme, which is based upon the Stanford parser? s popular scheme (de Marneffe and Manning, 2008), and a fast, accurate dependency parser with non-projectivity support (Section 4) and additional integrated semantic annotation modules for automatic preposition sense disambiguation and noun compound interpretation (Section 5)
clean_text: In this paper, we describe 1) a new dependency conversion (Section 3) of the Penn Treebank (Marcus, et al, 1993) along with the associated dependency label scheme, which is based upon the Stanford parser's popular scheme (de Marneffe and Manning, 2008), and a fast, accurate dependency parser with non-projectivity support (Section 4) and additional integrated semantic annotation modules for automatic preposition sense disambiguation and noun compound interpretation (Section 5).
